bright amber/copper color with a tall rocky light tan head & good lacing.  aroma is dusty sweet caramel malt, some funky yeast, and some fresh thyme sprigs (but not strong).  a little sweet in the aroma.  good to high carbonation, flavor is caramel malt, then some dry spicyness like white pepper and spinach greens.  some tanginess too.  I didnt get as much of the herbs everyone is talking about!

Drinking a yet untried Fantôme ale is always an adventure. This hazy amber brew with a creamy beige head reminded me of being in the secondary waiting room at a doctors office, the room you go into after waiting an hour, take off your clothes, sit on a stainless steel table, and wait another hour.  Why? Because the aroma is strongly medicinal, like the antiseptics that you smell in such a place.  The blending of spices and herbs goes wild in the nose (mine, at least), what with the additional mint, tea leaves, ginger, chamomile, pepper, nutmeg, lilacs, pine needles.... Its soft in the mouth, gently carbonated and is a mixture of malt, medicine, and soap - -  but somehow remains an enjoyable drink.  Im not giving this a very high rating, but rather an appreciative one.  Ill be trying this again (n again) to try to make some sense of it all.  Which may be futile.  It is a Fantôme ale, after all.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>
Pours with a dense but not long lasting head. Taste is spicy like autumn leaves. Lots of tree sap, coriander, tea, soap thats sweet but somewhat dry. This will be awesome with 2* years on it.

Slightly hazy auburn with a dense, thick tan head.  Crazy aroma of all kinds of spices and herbs.  Pine, rosemary, juniper, sage, sweet caramel, light citrus, cinnamon, white pepper, freshly cut grass and shrubs, a touch of brown sugar, orange zest and maybe some light alcohol.  A retronasal experience shows bits anise and perhaps a little living vegetation.   A nice, full body with a light, soft carbonation.  The flavors are cooler than I expected from the nose.  The sweet malt backbone meshes superbly with the fairly strong herbal character.  The interplay of sweetness and spicy, bitter herbal qualities are really unique.  Perhaps a little strange in terms of everyday drinking, but enjoyable nonetheless.  All told, this is another winner from Dany.  Well done and interesting as all get out.

(750ml bottle) Opaque, dull amber body with medium beige head.  Aroma medium sweet, tarragon, lemon peel, ginger, other herbs.  Taste is medium sweet, tarragon, white pepper, ginger, other herbs, light lime.  Medium body with a dry finish.  Not bad by any stretch, but not sure that I need to ever drink a tarragon beer again.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2006 Geez, what a strange beer! Smelled like mint and dust, but tasted like rosemary.
Very intense, yet not offensive at all. A beer that really demands that you take your time drinking it. Definitely for the adventurous, but not at all a novelty.

Sampled at Logans loft during GABF RateBeer party 2005.  One of the more bizarre offerings of the evening.  Amber gold in my glass, hazy with a light and good-looking head.  The aroma is jammed with herbs!  Smells like cooing in our kitchen with sage and thyme and pizza sauce lying around.  Flavor is very light and stays that way.  You get herby flavors of pizza type spices (oregano, thyme, etc.), very interesting and in no way is it bad.  Body is light and watery, in a refreshing way.  Dont know when and with what you would drink this, but it was good.

Pours a orange/cherry color body with a sticky white head.  Aroma reminds me a lot of Italian seasonings.  Like the mixed seasons I put on my pizza.  Complex spicey flavor (again, pizza spices) with the signature mild tartness in the finish.  Light effervescent palate.  Something I wouldnt have expected to want to drink a lot of.  Very well made.

Rusty copper, with a creamy, condensed milk head.
The most varied mix of spices as I have ever smelled...You got mint, ground pepper, basil, thyme, lavander, cloves, its like he emptied his spice rack in there!  And it was something new at every whiff.  Unbelievable stuff. 
Pretty complex taste, quite heavy on the spices.  In fact, it reminded me of my Dads spaghetti sauce!  The aftertaste had the bitterness of dandelion leaves.  The alcohol was nowhere to be felt, an impressive feat for an 8%.  I thought Id get tired of it after a while, but not at all.  Im glad I have a few more to cellar.

Sampled August 2005
Pours a slightly hazy,  pretty, ruby-orange color that is topped by a light cream-tan colored head that is held aloft by a persistent, good carbonation.  Wow, the aroma is quite interesting, it is fully herbal with notes of sage, thyme, rosemary & pine being quite evident.  Underneath the herbs is a nice fruitiness reminiscent of plums and raisins, there is a bit of a tart citrusy note here too.  Reminds me a bit of a German herbal liquor.

The taste is fairly dry up front, with just an ever so soft touch of sweetness.  As the herbal qualities of this beer take hold, it dries out considerably in the finish.  What an interesting beer, I really almost dont know what to say.  The beer has a definite tartness to it, which is especially evident in the first half of a draught of this beer.  The tartness and the fruitiness of this beer make me think of a tart orange.  As this beer warms up it becomes quite a bit softer and smoother as it looses some carbonation as well.  The herbal note is still quite evident though with Sage leading the lineup.

This beer is almost an aperitif, it would be perfect preceding a night of noshing on roasted lamb, but the herbal character also make it useful as a digestif.  All in all a very interesting beer from Dany.  I really am enjoying this, even though the balance is perhaps a little bit too much on the herbal side.

Pours a hazy rusty orange with a medium off white head that sticks around. Aroma of sharp rosemary, citrus, hay, pepper, and some sweet malt. Flavor is of rosemary, a very mild citrus and a watery maltiness. Thin body. Palate is watery. Interesting but the sharp herbiness is a bit too overbearing for me.
MdlB05:  Lightly cloudy orange color with a creamy white head, aroma has hay, straw, pepper and other spices.  Medium bodied with a gritty mineral texture, starts and ends lightly acidic and bitter.

Sage!  Woah!  Have had this a few times and maybe they havent been this fresh.  The label looked a bit different from the bottle on the wall collection so it is newer than some.  If you get a bottle with the bright green label, age it a bit.  Otherwise, its another excellent Fantome product with that house sourness/funk.  Oh yeah, and there has to be some sage in it and if you have cooked with sage (or brewed with it?!?) you know a little goes a long way.  Cant wait to try an aged bottle again.  Thanks Fly.

Bottle.  Hazy orangey amber pour.  For the aroma, all I can say is "Holy Rosemary Batman".  The aroma was loaded with rosemary.  Other herby components come through as well, I noted sage here as well.  Also a little earthy funky notes.  Huge floral and herby flavors as well - tons of rosemary.  Some earthy funk and grassy notes too.  And a moderate malt backing, so it didnt seem like I was drinking herby water.  Almost unnoticable bitter end.  Maybe Im just sensitive to rosemary, but it took me back to when I used to grow herb plants, and my rosemary bushes were always the most fragrent.  I loved this beer, but for me, the intense rosemary obscured other more delicate flavors and aromas.  I agree with goldtwins too - because of its huge herbiness, this guy would go awesome with certain foods that couple with sage and rosemary.

Pours a murk orange with good head and lacing. Spicy  and herbal ( a lot of sage) nose. Big sage flavors with rosemary and some earthy bitterness. 	I like this one a lot. (I love sage!) It is not for everyone. The last bottle of this I had a few years ago did not seem to have as much sage flavors in it. Maybe with age those flavors mellow. Great beer.  Thanks Fly!

Poured a hazy orange amber color with a small off white head.  Huge herbal aroma.  A whole potpouri (sp?) of herbs but I seem to pick up lavendar the most.  Also notes of pepper.  The aroma was dry almost like smelling powder.  The flavor is also pretty big with herbs and spice.  The beer started and finish dry.  While the aroma and flavor are huge it really doesnt feel out of balance.  This would be a great beer to have with a meal.  Very drinkable I just wish it wasnt as dry.

Slightly hazy amber w/ frothy, off-white foam. Aroma is malty & spicy (ginger, cinnamon) w/ some herbal & yeasty notes. Lively, effervescent feel. Flavour is sweet & spicy w/ a solid tartness. Warm, peppery finish.

A gigantic thank you to Secret Santa for this one.  Pours turbid dark copper with a big, creamy, off-white head.  Aroma of cloves, hops, citrus, black pepper, rosemary, and oregano.  The taste is solidly hoppy with tons of spices, including oregano, black pepper, rosemary, and coriander.  Smooth finish.  Perhaps the spiciest beer I have ever encountered, which was almost like drinking liquid pizza at times.

(Bottle 75 cl) Beautiful orangey red with an almost warm glow. Slightly sourish with a decent hopping. But first and foremost this is spicy, spicy, spicy - and Im talking spices you usually find in cooking: basil, thyme and sage. Weird - as expected. And a strange ghost indeed... 090601
This bottle poured amber with small off white head. Nose agressive spices, all kinds. Taste was flowery as well. Not sure if I liked this.

[bottle at RBSG]
Almost clear, light brownish-orange with a white ring.  Spicy orange aroma with mustard, a little hops, and ver faint pine-sol (solventy).  Dry, woody and bitter, with some solventy pine.  Light body and moderate carbonation.  I usually love Fantome beers, but I think this is the worst one I have had yet.  This was one of the last beers that I had at RBSG 2005, Montréal and perhaps my palate was becoming fatigued...

Orangish amber in color, off white head, slight haze to the beer. Very spicy aroma, earthy, along with a touch of Fantome funk. Flavor was lightly skuned, however and it definitely made things not go so well together with the spice and funk. Medium bodied. I would like to try again because this may be really nice if it werent for the catty flavor.

Only wish I hadnt been so anxious to try this as I strongly believe that it would greatly improve with age. Perhaps I should raise my ratings as underneath was what appeared to be an excellent beer, but being crammed in my nostrils and rubbed across my tongue was an amazingly potent herbal (my "crew" said sage, and I had to agree - with another stating perhaps fenugreek). The potency level was like having plucked some fresh from the garden and rolling it between fingers under a nostril. Amazing that it came through so strongly. Regret I bought only one bottle.

Sadly it was mildy skunked. I have found this to be not abnormal in most of the Fantome product line. Pours with a light haze in the orange amber spectrum. Toasted grain with a little peach for an aroma. More of the same with some bolstering of pear syrup and apricot. Yeast. And wheat. And a weak ending. Some barnyard and cheese in the finish. Im shrugging.

Bottle sampled @ RBSG 05 (Montréal) Grand TastingNose of thyme, rosehips, light hops and chocolate. Lightly skunky and full bodied. Very rich and creamy flavor with that trademark Fantôme yeast funk in the tail. Another tasty treat from Dany.

07.10.05, 07.19.05  750ml bottles, 1st at RBSG.  Copper pour, light haze, lasting khaki head.  Crazed mess of spices is intoxicating.  Nutmeg, rosemary, spruce, forest, dust, mint.  Flavor follows suit with additions of juniper, lots of pepper.  Some banana comes through.  Awesome.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2005 Thanks to hopdog for the trade! Bottle - corked and capped. Like jeffc666, my bottle also has the 1711 in white on the back of the bottle. Also has the UPC code blocked with white-out. (NOTE: willblake was kind enough to pass this info on: "The white out on the UPC and the 1711 is just the inventory system used by the beer store, Sommerville supersaver.") Clouded orange-ruby with a small foamy tanned head. Nose is a myriad of spices and herbs. Peppermint, Vicks Vaporub, suntan lotion, pepper, nutmeg, yeast, ginger, fresh flowers, and god knows what else. Unique aroma and I tip my hat to Dany! Taste is herbal and medicinal and, dare I say....strange..... More mint, yeast, cough medicine (this isnt like a Flaming Moe, is it???), pine, fresh flowers, ginger, light peppery notes, light hops, and probably some stuff growing in the wild that Dany found on a walk in the woods. This is a mish-mash of flavors that is nearly indescribable by me. Body is medium and laden with a medicinal feel throughout. Light carbonation feel to it. The finish delves deeper into the ol medicine cabinet. Fresh mint, medicinal herbs, light hops, pepper, BIG ginger, pine needles, and other odd spices. This is what I think when I think Fantome - unique, odd, tasty and finely crafted. I dont know what Danys doing in Soy, but hes doing it right!

750 ml bottle sent to me by the esteemed jimmack04. Has the number 1711 written on the back in white marker, not sure it means anything just thought I would point it out in case it ends up being the meaning of life. Murky orange-brown with that trademark lasting manila colored fantastic Fantome head.  Lace is also quite the site. The aroma, as it wafts first out of the bottle then out of the glass, is first a funky mélange of yeast and spice that signifies almost all beers from this little Belgian farm house. Further reflection brings out a lot of different kind of spices and herbs: ginger, mint, cut flower stems, and crushed pine needles, you name it is in here! The flavor is tres bizzaro. All that was in the aroma is there and it makes for a unique experience. An almost overwhelming mint-pine flavor dominates all throughout. It is quite bitter, though not in a hoppy way. It is very interesting. Medium soft palate dry finish with an everlasting presence from the flavor explosion so recently experienced. Far and away the strangest beer I have had from this brewery. Not my favorite but I am tickled that I finally got to experience it.

Bottle... RBSG2005... Very lightly hazy copper ale with a small, frothy, off-white head. Decent retention. All I can smell is the lavender. Malty flavor is a touch Flemish. Well-balanced, spicy and earthy. Medium-bodied and fizzy. Herbal, dry finish. Too interesting and original to dislike... even if its spice profile includes one of my least favorites.

Bottle.  Orange-amber in colour.  Average sized lingering tan coloured head that left lace on the side of the glass.  Huge aroma of pepper - all different kinds of it - along with a medley of spices and herbs.  The flavour was quite spicy up front, lots of pepper and herbs, cream, quite funky and extremely complex and enjoyable.  Bitter mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes with a long pepper and spice burn.  Very strange indeed but equally enjoyable.

Pour was amber with a small tan head...smelled like a doctors office...antiseptic and wet leaves being raked from the lawn...taste was over spiced and overly bitter...I was sadly unimpressed and disappointed...

Sampled at the RBSG 05 bottle tasting courtesy of Dickinsonbeer:  Pours a clear copper with a thin off-white head.  Aroma reminds me of a grassy Italian seasoning of some sort with a touch of garlic butter and earthy malt, very unique and complex.  Body starts nicely dry, caramely malty and full, but not very sweet.  Interesting dry, grassy complexity but could use a touch more sweetness.

(750ml bottle) Sampled at RBSG 2005 in Montreal. Nose of fresh hemp. Pours a thin dissipated, white head with a peppered-filled sediment mixed within an amber body. Flavour is spicey good but a tad thin. Heavy ginger.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2008 2005 RBSG Montreal Friday Night Tasting. Golden amber colour with a frothy off-white head. Spruce, juniper, caramel, rosemary, and herbal aroma. Eucalyptus, juniper, rosemary, light caramel, and light citrus flavours. Light, dry, but very refreshing. Yummy.

Bottle provided by Hopdog and sampled in a Duval snifter:
Pours a hazy reddish amber hue with a lasting frothy head and good lace. The aroma has notes of sour apple, mint, oregano, juniper berry, clover, funky brett and Belgium yeast. I dig the nose, but hope it doesnt translate to the flavors, but ... The taste starts extremely herbal and quite honestly way over-the-top, oregano and basil out the arse. Sure I get some nice yeast and minty tones, but those herbs just get in the way of it all. I can not enjoy the flavor of this beer, sorry Dany but this does not work. I so was looking forward to this and sadly it is the first Fantôme I dislike. Well good news is my cellar is still stocked with many Fantôme beers I do like. Right there with Anchor OSA 2004 and Traquair Jacobite Ale as extremely OVER SPICED beers.

Sample courtesy of egajdzis (thanks!) Poured a medium and cloudy amber color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of fresh mint leaves and basil with some citrus. Tastes of the same although there was a lot going on there that I couldnt exactly pin point. Alcohol content hidden. Lighter body. Ill have to give this one closer attention in the near future. Strange Ghost was a good name for this one as Ive never smelled or tasted anything as Strange (which isnt a bad thing!).

750ml. bottle. Dark amber color with a medium sized off white head. Wild aroma of oregano, thyme, pepper and other unidentifiable herbs and spices. Flavor reminded me of a saison with mixed Italian seasonings thrown in. Really odd combination of flavors that grows on you the more you drink it. Some floral notes in the flavor as well. Went through my cupboard trying to identify the different herbs and spices in the beer. To me the oregano really stood out, which makes me wonder how this beer would be with Italian food.

Poured a reddish amber color with a large, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of vanilla, barnyard, tons of herbs and spices, mint, basil, lemongrass and a touch of hops.  I am getting all sorts of green herbs in the taste, more basil, tobacco, citrus, and no alcohol at all.  I certainly see why this is listed as a S/H/V and not a saison.

Bottle. Wild looking carbonation. Bubbles flinging themselves against the inside of my glass, trying to escape. Hazy strawberry appearance with a mountain of a head. Pungent, fruit and horse aroma with eucalyptsus and manzanita. The first flavor I get is that of how cedar incense smells when it burns. There are some herbal medicinal flavors underlying. Soft on the palate. Rosemary shows itself as the ale warms. The beer walks a fine line but pulls it off nicely.

750ml from Monks Cafe in Philadelphia:  The bottle was served at fridge temperature, so I took my time with the beer to allow it to warm.  This was certainly a unique beer - one that caused me difficulty putting my finger on the exact spices I was smelling and tasting.  Deep rusty-copper-amber, near opaque, with a small lasting beige head.  Aroma: Theres a lot going on in this aroma dominated by herbs.  Rosemary, basil, lavender, pencil shavings, yeast, ceder, tree bark, and sweet malt all make their appearances at times.  Taste: I sat around with my friend discussing this, trying to nail it down.  We came to this conclusion: Eucalyptus, mint, pepper, sage, thyme, green planty flavors, stale hops, green tea, with an earthy sweet caramel malt adding to the sweetness.  Quite sweet and cloying(without going over the top), lively carbonation, full creamy mouthfeel, does dry somewhat in the finish.  This really is just a masterfully crafted beer, and quite unique even to the Fantome line, though I cant say I could drink more than one in a sitting.

750 ml bottle. Clear golden orange in color with a thin head. Aroma of spices and herbs.  Rosemary, Thyme? Hoppy. Spicey flavor. Rosemary.  Finish is dry. Smooth tasting. Nice hop flavor.  Medium bodied. Decent beer.

750 ml. Golden orange, thin head, clear. Aroma can be described by one word: Rosemary. Now on to the flavor. Rosemary up front, then the beer kicks in, with light maltiness and old hop flavor and bitterness. Dry on the finish. Round flavors, and the Rosemary can be a bit overpowering at times, but kudos for originality. Would go well with steak, I may add, and would definitely be good for a marinade, if one was inclined to waste good beer.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Pours a dark somewhat murky amber/light brown with a smallish beige head which lasts and leaves good lace.  Aroma is initially a hint of ginger, but then gives way to some oregano, minty thyme, then a thick smell of rosemary is noticed.   Flavor is smooth with a touch of sweetness from the malts but the flavor is dominated by lots of spices and herbs.  More basil and rosemary in the flavor.  Moderate bitterness from the hops (if any) but probably from all the herbs.  Smooth finish.  This one started out hard to get used to and I wasnt too thrilled with it, but then I started to like it more and more, but then by the end I kinda got sick of the spices again.  One of the most unique beers I have ever had.

Sampled at le Mondial de la bière 2005. Pours a dark copper color with lots of floaties, thin white head. Strange aroma of oregano, herbs, grass, maybe rosemay and other spices. Amazing flavor of oregano, rosemary, herbs and grass. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation.

Hazy amber hue, tan-colored foamy head, herbal dry spices of fines herbes, like basil, thyme, parseley, rosemary, pale malt and yeasty aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with grassy note, herbal character of fines herbes of basil, rosemary, thyme, parseley even hint of pepper, pale malt in a leafy bitterness finish.

Cedar, leaves, lavender, sage, white pepper and celery in the spicy aroma.  Clear caramel-copper coloured body with a decent and lasting fine-bubbled off-white head that leaves some fair lacing.  Cedar, peppery spiciness and yeasty flavours mingle nicely.  Smooth and creamy texture with a gentle effervesence that caresses the tongue and cheeks.  Truly a unique artisanal beer from a master craftsman.  Sampled at Mondial de la Bière 2005.

Sample at the Mondial de la Biere.  Copper-bronze, almost clear, lots of visible carbonation, lasting head and some lace...cedar/birch-bark nose, amazing sharp and full of stingy herbs, lavender and a bit of brown sugar, wow...dry, strong herbal character in the body, twiggy with a velvet-soft mouthfeel, luscious carbonation, just a bit of sugar...really over-the-top, the first thing I thought of was root beer, a dry, alcoholic root beer.  Thats a good thing, and so is this beer.

Bottle. copper body with small floaties and a medium size head. wow, this is a crazy aroma! Flowers, vegetables, hemp, christmas trees, yeast, and dusty hops are all evident in the aroma...plus about a dozen other things I cant identify. Sharp earthy vegetable flavour. Light carbonation.  This has to be the most interesting beer Ive ever tried. Awesome.

Rusty orange. Extremely foamy head, sticking on the glass like theres no end, beautiful lacing capacity. Awesome core pencil shavings yeasty nose. Granite rockiness, overwhelming wood notes. Incredibly complex and jumping at you. Lime and pepper yeasty interplays. It smells like chips, it smells like cedar resin and spruce. Very green aroma, tea like chamomile notes with more spice depth reminiscent of sage and thyme. Very fun to sniff and decorticate, but theres no way you can figure whats in there. Rooty greenish flavours. Mellow chillies, spice blend, cumin and maybe even salt. It is very dry in mouth, campfire like or moreso sawdust like dryness, earthy and highly pleasant, just not as enticing as the fiery aroma. Creamy palate, light carbonation, perhaps not as lively as most Fantôme, but even more original and unique.

Ambrée, semi opaque, plein de minuscules dépôts présents partout dans le verre.  Grosse mousse épaisse, crémeuse et passablement persistante.  Amalgame darômes inhabituels et intéressants; Sauge, thym, poivre blanc, lavande, racine et bois de cèdre.  Corps de densité moyenne, texture crémeuse.  Cette bière ne possède pas toute les mêmes caractéristiques habituelles des produits de cette brasserie mais est tout aussi étonnante.  Passablement sèche en bouche.  Échantillon mondial de la bière, Juin 2005.

Sample at the Mondiale 2005: Poured an extremely cloudy color ale with big thick head with good retention. Aroma of juniper and rosemary are extremely easy to detect. Taste is a mix between the rosemary and the Belgian yeast with a real farmhouse taste behind it. I really enjoyed this non-conventional beer.
Amber colour. Amazing aromas of thyme, fennel. Light-medium mouthfeel , undercarbonated- wonderful, creamy, citrus, ginger, anise, lemon Herbal tea

Verre de dégustation (provenant dune bouteille verte de 750 ml) au Mondial de la Bière 2005 (Montréal, QC). Arôme: Explosion dépices et dherbes (Menthe, thym, gingembre, poivre entre autre). Apparence: Bière brune voilée. Aucun col. Aucune bulle. Fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Les mêmes épices perçus en arômes reviennent. Court arrière goût. Palette: Les corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Arrière goût dépices. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. (Rating #177)

UPDATED: APR 18, 2007 2005 bottle at the Mondial.  Hazy, copper-amber, muddy, brown.  Lots of yeast suspended.  Head provides lacing.  Beige, somewhat retained, but slowly works its way to a ring.  Aroma is very herbal, bitter, astringent dry, but the yeast flavor and aroma is amazing.  Dry tea.  Flavor is vinegar, herbs, leafy/fuzzy green hops, hemp.  Quite oily on the palate, though not watery.  Not much sweetness, low tingly carbonation.  Very very herbally, wow.  Medium body.
Mondial de la Bière de Montréal 2005. Thym au nez et en bouche. Très spéciale, très bonne. Bien balancée avec le malt et le houblon.

Cloudy copper pour, high carbonation makes a large, fizzy head that quickly settles to a small ring of foam - spicy aroma,  lemongrass, lime leaves, ginger, some earthiness and grass, grain - light, airy carbonation in the mouthfeel - bready malts, ginger again, herbal tea-like qualities - has the earthiness of a biere de garde - I detect some hops, orange peel - light and refreshing, yet complex and flavorful at the same time - who could ask for more?

Lime cookies on the nose. lots of spice, pepper, clove, nutmeg, grains of paradise,stinging nettle?,cumin, curry and green tea. wonderful mouthfeel slightly oily and viscous. Big lingering finish. awesome stuff.

Ruddy translucent copper with a splotchy head.  Nose is an unbelievable combo of cloves, brown sugar, pepper, and....go ask JorisPPattyn.  The mouth takes all of wich and adds licorish root, anis, sasparilla, soap and a touch of malt.  Finishes with aquavite.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2005 Cheesy, hand-made label is hard to look past; but Im not judging a cover here. Head is thin, but somewhat lasting. Color is amber, which blends - from top to bottom - into a hazy yellow-orange. Interesting nose, with wafts of herbal tea, pumpkin pie and lemon yogurt. First sip made my left eyebrow raise. A couple seconds later my second eyebrow raised. My tongue went for a roller coaster ride for a second there; didnt know if it was fun or I was gonna hurl. Soon realized it was positive. Smooth malts up front, quickly turn into an explosion of spices, many reminiscent of teas Ive had before. Strong lemony citrus exudes throughout, occasionally morphing into tangerine, lime, and back to lemon. Lively carbonation. Fizzy, sugary and soft-drink-like at times. Some sourness. Dryish, spicy finish. What a weird, albeit well-made, fricken beer.

Dull amber (yeast in suspension, despite careful pouring), with orange-red shine.
Nose is  - GOD WHAT? - cypress? myrrh? incense? - no - it's the smell of bog myrtle in an Irish moor.
Taste: WOOW! This is the taste of kaffir-limes ("wild limes"), if you've ever had the opportunity to taste those, together with bog myrtle, cypress. Yet there is a subterranean sweetness. It's like being in a late autumn garden, next to the cypress plant, wild mushrooms coming up, and in the field next, the winter leeks are being covered, marvellous!
Mouthfeel: oily, slick, but in NO way repulsive.
Aftertaste: what I described as myrrh or cypress, now turns to a resiny flavour: cedar, copalite, Retsina. THAT'S it: this is the Retsina under the beers. Strange (ghost) indeed. I LOVE it. I don't like Retsina. Go figure.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2007 New batch fresh from Shelton (whatever that might mean...late 06 or early 07).
Head is initially small, frothy/fizzy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy medium to dark amber, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain, cookie), lightly yeasty (barnyard), with notes of nutmeg, sage, cave earth, moss. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly astringent. The batch I tried at RBSG 2005 was extremely medicinal in the nose, and very strongly aromatic (didnt rate that one, as I didnt have my own glass of it).  This one is fairly mild in the nose, quite a change.  Its still doing most of the malt balance with sourness, as it was many years ago.  Its not very bitter at all this time, in fact.  So...hmm...interesting, but not that great this time.  Aging it will probably not help much.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2005 Antiphlogistine fumes reign over this senile voodoo potion...Muddy green spices (rosemary, mint) and vegetables are plentiful in the cauldron, and the aroma stuns the waking nostrils...The voodoo sorcerer is wearing milky pepper on his ear lobes and forehead and shakes his head over his concoction in order to drop in the right amount...This beer, claims the sorcerer, is for those who are comfortable in their understanding of beer...It will slap them twice and bite their tongue out...Very dry, bitter and frothy, the flavors are a tad less expressive than the marvelous nose, but still present cohesion and inspiration...Need I say that the word "original" would be a huge understatement?...

Not as good as others ive had from Fantome. Malty flavour, sour and acidic, and a gingery spicy flavour, it definitely hides the alcohol, a bit fizzy, but its decent. If you see it, you have to give it a go.
